questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found lying on the sidewalk. The patient was noted to have pinpoint pupils and a slow respiratory rate.  An intravenous μ-opiate antagonist was administered to the patient before arrival. Upon initial assessment, the patient is slumped over but is responsive to sternal rub. He states, “Leave me alone. I just want to ride this out.” The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Track marks are noted on the upper and lower extremities. Which of the following effects of the drug described in this vignette is unlikely to exhibit tolerance?
questions.solution:
Opiates are used to treat acute moderate to severe pain. The primary effects of opiates that do not exhibit tolerance are pupillary constriction (miosis) and constipation.    

Tolerance refers to an increase in the dose needed to produce a given pharmacological effect. In the setting of opiate use, this phenomenon results in part from desensitization of the opiate receptors. With prolonged activation by an agonist, the μ-opioid receptors become phosphorylated by various intracellular kinases, directly desensitizing the receptor or uncoupling the receptor from its G-protein.    

Tolerance is an important concept in opiate use disorder. As patients require higher and higher doses to achieve the same analgesic or euphoric effects, they are at greater risk of overdosing and subsequently developing life-threatening respiratory depression and apnea.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pupillary constriction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Euphoria :
Incorrect: Euphoria is one of the effects of opiates that exhibit tolerance, meaning that higher and higher doses of the substance are required to achieve the same effect.   
❌ Analgesia:
Incorrect: Analgesia is one of the effects of opiates that exhibit tolerance, meaning that higher and higher doses of the substance are required to achieve the same effect. Patients with chronic pain and opiate use may intermittently switch agents to offset this effect.   
❌ Respiratory depression:
Incorrect: Respiratory depression is one of the effects of opiates that exhibit tolerance.   
❌ Emesis:
Incorrect: Emesis occasionally occurs with the administration of opiates. It is a side effect of opiates that does exhibit tolerance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who is currently post-op day three following an open cholecystectomy is being evaluated for new-onset confusion. The patient’s surgical course was uneventful, and he was recovering as expected apart from occasional diaphoresis and tremors. This evening, the patient became agitated, shouting in his room alone. Past medical history is significant for schizophrenia, polysubstance use, and major depression. The patient currently takes risperidone and venlafaxine. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 188/95 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a diaphoretic and tremulous male attempting to get out of bed. Pupils are equal and reactive to light bilaterally. The cardiopulmonary exam is non-contributory. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient who is three days post-op presents with an acute change in mental status, diaphoresis, tremors, agitation, hypertension, and hallucinations–a presentation highly suggestive of delirium tremens (DT) secondary to alcohol withdrawal.

DT begins between 72 and 96 hours following a patient’s last drink and typically presents with acute and fluctuating disturbances in consciousness, confusion, psychomotor agitation, inattention, and hallucinations unrelated to a preexisting condition. DT is also accompanied by extreme autonomic hyperactivity, including fever, severe tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, and seizures.

DT differs from alcoholic hallucinosis in that the latter presents within 12-24 hours and does not present with significant vital sign disturbances. Alcoholic hallucinosis does not carry significant mortality, whereas DT is associated with a mortality rate as high as 5%.

The timing and characterization of the various manifestations of alcohol withdrawal are outlined in the chart and graph below.  




Option Analysis

❌ Neuroleptic malignant syndrome  :
Incorrect: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a rare but severe complication of antipsychotic use; it presents with mental status changes, muscular rigidity, and autonomic instability. Given this patient’s history and physical exam findings, his delirium is more suggestive of delirium tremens, a severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal.
❌ Cocaine toxicity  :
Incorrect: Cocaine toxicity can present with autonomic hyperactivity and psychosis; however, given this patient’s history and physical exam findings, his delirium is more suggestive of delirium tremens, a severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal.  
❌ Malignant hyperthermia  :
Incorrect: Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by hyperpyrexia (usually > 104°F/40°C), muscle rigidity, and autonomic instability which usually presents immediately following the administration of succinylcholine or inhaled volatile anesthetics. Given this patient’s history and physical exam findings, his delirium is more suggestive of delirium tremens, a severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal.  
✅ Delirium tremens  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Opioid intoxication  :
Incorrect: Opioid intoxication leads to respiratory depression, lethargy, and constricted pupils. Given this patient’s history and physical exam findings, his delirium is more suggestive of delirium tremens, a severe manifestation of alcohol withdrawal.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the emergency department to evaluate progressive, worsening shortness of breath. The patient cannot walk from his bed to the bathroom without becoming short of breath. He also reports worsening abdominal distension and leg swelling for the past several months. Past medical history is unremarkable, and the patient does not take any medications. The patient has been smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the past 15 years and drinks 10-12 beers daily. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a laterally displaced and enlarged apical impulse. The patient has moderate abdominal distension and pitting edema to the knees. Bibasilar rales are appreciated on pulmonary auscultation. Laboratory results are demonstrated below. Chest x-ray demonstrates an enlargement of the cardiac silhouette and pulmonary vascular congestion. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a dilated left ventricle with an increased ventricular cavity size; left ventricular ejection fraction is 23%. Coronary angiography is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple features of systolic heart failure, including diffuse anasarca and diminished ejection fraction. In addition, this patient has laboratory evidence suggestive of chronic alcohol use, including macrocytosis and transaminitis. In the absence of other inciting factors, this patient’s presentation suggests alcoholic cardiomyopathy, one of the long-term complications of alcohol use disorder.

Alcohol use disorder has serious long-term health consequences, including dilated cardiomyopathy, pancreatitis, and liver steatosis, steatohepatitis, fibrosis, and cirrhosis. Alcohol use disorder is also associated with an increased risk of developing several cancers, including oral, pharyngeal, esophageal, liver, and breast cancer. Patients with chronic alcohol use can also develop thiamine deficiency–increasing their risk of developing Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Long-term heavy alcohol use is also associated with early-onset dementia, risk of trauma, and falls.

The DSM-V diagnostic criteria for alcohol use disorder are outlined in the table below.  


Option Analysis

✅ Chronic alcohol use  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thiamine deficiency:
Incorrect: Thiamine deficiency (which may be due to chronic alcohol consumption) can manifest as wet beriberi–a condition characterized by dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and high-output heart failure. However, patients usually present with other features of thiamine deficiency (e.g., loss of appetite, irritability, tingling sensations, and muscle weakness).  
❌ Cigarette smoking  :
Incorrect: Cigarette smoking is an important risk factor for developing coronary artery disease, but it does not directly cause dilated cardiomyopathy. In addition, this patient’s coronary angiography is unremarkable.  
❌ Hypothyroidism  :
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy can occur secondary to hypothyroidism. However,  this patient does not have other symptoms of hypothyroidism, and hypothyroidism would not explain this patient’s laboratory findings.  
❌ Viral myocarditis  :
Incorrect: Viral myocarditis (e.g., caused by parvovirus B19, human herpesvirus 6, coxsackievirus, echovirus, or HIV) can result in heart failure and dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). However, this patient has no other signs of an underlying viral illness.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician’s office to evaluate recurrent headaches and sneezing for six weeks. The patient’s parent says, “Initially, I thought it was a seasonal flu, but I have also noticed nose bleeds that occur spontaneously.” The patient has been spending most of his free time in his bedroom, skipping meals, and he becomes irritable when asked to participate in family activities. The patient says that he is doing well academically and socially. Past medical history is significant for asthma which is managed with albuterol. Vitals are within normal limits. A 10- lb (4.5 kg) weight loss has been noted since the patient’s last physical five months ago. Physical examination reveals the smell of gasoline on the patient’s breath and a flaky, eczematous rash surrounding the mouth and nasolabial folds. The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. Neurological examination reveals numbness and tingling of the hands and feet, bilateral hand tremors, and decreased deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with headaches, agitation, anorexia, weight loss, and a characteristic perioral rash consistent with recreational inhalant use. The most frequently used inhalants include glue, shoe polish, gasoline, nitrous oxide or "whippets," and spray paint. These substances are inhaled by “sniffing,” “huffing,” or “bagging.” Inhalant use is particularly prevalent in children and young adults.

Acute effects of inhalant intoxication include euphoria, dizziness, slurred speech, hallucinations, headache, delusions, and loss of consciousness. A single session of inhalant use may trigger lethal cardiac dysrhythmias, a sequela termed “sudden sniffing death.” Additional symptoms include gastrointestinal upset (e.g. abdominal cramps and nausea), cardiovascular toxicity (e.g. arrhythmias or myocardial infarction), and respiratory symptoms (e.g., coughing, wheezing). The classic rash refers to a peri-oral and midface of eczematous dermatitis with erythema, inflammatory changes, and pruritus caused by the drying effects of inhaled hydrocarbons. Long-term effects of inhalant use include anorexia and weight loss, neurocognitive impairment, and cerebellar dysfunction. Withdrawal symptoms can be distressing and include excessive sweating, insomnia, restlessness, sleep disturbances, and headaches.


Option Analysis

❌ Opioid use:
Incorrect: Opioid intoxication typically presents with euphoria, respiratory and CNS depression, and miosis (pinpoint pupils). This patient’s perioral rash, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and neurological deficits suggest inhalant use.  
❌ Systemic lupus erythematosus  :
Incorrect: While systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest with CNS symptoms, the characteristic malar rash usually spares nasolabial folds. This patient’s perioral rash, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and neurological deficits suggest inhalant use.  
❌ Cocaine use  :
Incorrect: Cocaine intoxication manifests with symptoms of agitation, weight loss, paranoia, and tremor. Due to vasoconstriction and ischemic necrosis, chronic use may lead to a perforated nasal septum. A perioral rash, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and neurological deficits are not typically observed.  
✅ Inhalant use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sedative-hypnotic use:
Incorrect: Sedative-hypnotic intoxication usually presents with CNS depression, confusion, stupor, and coma. This patient’s perioral rash, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and neurological deficits suggest inhalant use.

questions.text: A 1-day-old male infant is brought to the newborn nursery two hours after birth. He was born via vaginal delivery at 38 weeks gestation. The infant’s mother did not receive prenatal care. Family history is unremarkable for hereditary disorders. Weight and length are at the 5th percentile. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals microcephaly, short palpebral fissures, a thin vermillion border, and a smooth philtrum. A harsh holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border on cardiac auscultation. This infant’s physical exam findings are most likely secondary to in-utero exposure to which of the following?
questions.solution:
This infant’s presentation with a low birth weight and dysmorphic facial features (microcephaly, short palpebral fissures, a thin vermillion border, and smooth philtrum) is consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS).

Maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy has varying effects on the fetus, and no amount of alcohol has been deemed safe for consumption during pregnancy. Ethanol and its toxic metabolites (e.g., acetaldehyde) pass freely through the placenta, and the immature fetal liver does not carry the necessary enzymes to metabolize these products. Specifically, ethanol interferes with cell division, growth, and differentiation–resulting in derangements in multiple organ systems. Alcohol-induced brain damage includes microcephaly and deficits in the corpus callosum, cerebellum, and basal ganglia leading to abnormal reflexes, tone, and coordination. Dysmorphic facial features include short palpebral fissures, a thin vermillion border, and a smooth philtrum. Other features include limb dislocation and cardiac defects.



Option Analysis

❌ Heroin  :
Incorrect: Infants exposed to heroin in-utero present with neonatal abstinence syndrome. This syndrome is characterized by high-pitched crying, irritability, difficulty feeding, and autonomic dysfunction. It is not associated with dysmorphic features or congenital anomalies.  
❌ Diethylstilbestrol  :
Incorrect: Exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) in utero can result in reproductive tract anomalies, infertility, and an increased risk for certain cancers. DES exposure is not associated with dysmorphic facial features.  
❌ Cocaine  :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to cocaine can result in low birth weight, jitteriness, excessive sucking, and a hyperactive Moro reflex. Cocaine exposure is not associated with dysmorphic facial features.  
❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to warfarin can result in low birth weight and dysmorphic facial features including nasal hypoplasia, microphthalmia, far set eyes, and strabismus. However, this patient’s characteristic features of microcephaly, short palpebral fissures, a thin vermillion border, and smooth philtrum are more consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome.  
✅ Ethanol  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 2-day-old female neonate is examined in the newborn nursery to evaluate poor feeding. The infant was born vaginally to a 28-year-old woman who did not receive consistent prenatal care during her pregnancy. The pregnancy was complicated by intrauterine growth restriction. The infant was breastfed normally until two hours ago when she became tachypneic and restless. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 85/min, and blood pressure is 60/35 mmHg. Physical examination shows increased tone in all extremities. The patient appears diaphoretic and has a high-pitched cry and occasional sneezes. There are no dysmorphic facial features. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this infant’s presentation?

choices.text: Nondisjunction resulting in an extra copy of chromosome 21
Fragile X mental retardation one gene mutation

questions.solution:
This 2-day-old infant presents with feeding difficulty, tachypnea, hypertonia, sneezing, and yawning; this presentation is characteristic of neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS).

NAS is a drug withdrawal syndrome that most commonly follows in utero exposure to opioids. NAS is characterized by hypertonia, autonomic instability (e.g., sweating and sneezing), irritability, poor sucking reflex, tachypnea, and seizures. The common symptoms of NAS are outlined in the image below. Affected patients often have biological mothers who received little or no prenatal care. There are also often underlying risk factors associated with opiate use (e.g. hepatitis C infection). Infants exposed to heroin in utero (short half-life) develop withdrawal features within 24 hours of birth. Withdrawal from the longer-acting opioids such as methadone or buprenorphine begins 24 to 72 hours after birth.

Treatment includes symptomatic care, including swaddling, providing frequent small feeds, and keeping the infant in a low-stimulation environment. Pharmacologic interventions include morphine or methadone that can be administered when the supportive care alone fails to treat withdrawal symptoms.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nondisjunction resulting in an extra copy of chromosome 21  :
Incorrect: Down syndrome is the most common cause of developmental delay and results from nondisjunction of chromosome 21. It is characterized by a flat facial profile, slanted palpebral fissures, and small-set ears. This patient has no dysmorphic facial features and instead demonstrates symptoms consistent with neonatal abstinence syndrome, which is the result of in utero exposure to opiates.  
✅ In utero exposure to opiates  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ In utero exposure to alcohol:
Incorrect: Prenatal alcohol exposure can result in the development of fetal alcohol syndrome, which is characterized by dysmorphic facial features including short palpebral fissures, a thin vermillion border, and a smooth philtrum. This patient has no dysmorphic facial features and instead demonstrates symptoms consistent with neonatal abstinence syndrome, which is the result of in utero exposure to opiates.  
❌ Fragile X mental retardation one gene mutation  :
Incorrect: Fragile X mental retardation one gene mutation results in Fragile X syndrome. It is characterized by a long, narrow face, macrocephaly, prominent forehead and chin, and large ears. This patient has no dysmorphic facial features and instead demonstrates symptoms consistent with neonatal abstinence syndrome, which is the result of in utero exposure to opiates.  
❌ In utero exposure to rubella  :
Incorrect: Congenital rubella syndrome is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, cardiac defects, cataracts, hepatosplenomegaly, and a blueberry muffin rash. This patient instead demonstrates symptoms consistent with neonatal abstinence syndrome, which is the result of in utero exposure to opiates.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man develops increasing anxiety, hand tremor, and nausea four days following an uncomplicated total knee replacement surgery. The patient is currently undergoing rehabilitation at a nearby facility and was transferred to the emergency department. Upon initial assessment, the patient states “There goes a bear!” The patient is currently receiving a continuous infusion of intravenous morphine. Past medical history includes advanced liver disease. The patient drinks seven cans of beer daily. He does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 177/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a confused middle-aged man with slight tremulousness and diaphoresis. Which of the following examination findings may also be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with evidence of tremors, anxiety, nausea, and transient hallucinations; this presentation is suggestive of alcohol withdrawal. Tongue fasciculations are a characteristic physical examination finding in patients with severe alcohol withdrawal.

The symptoms of alcohol withdrawal begin within 12-24 hours of last consumption and are characterized by autonomic hyperactivity, tremor, insomnia, nausea and vomiting, transient hallucinations (usually visual but can also be auditory and tactile), psychomotor agitation, anxiety, and tonic-clonic seizures.

Heavy, daily use of central nervous system (CNS) depressants (including alcohol) often results in withdrawal upon cessation of use. In general, withdrawal from depressants produces similar features:  anxiety, tremor, seizures, and insomnia. In contrast, intoxication with CNS depressants manifests with elevated mood, sedation, behavioral disinhibition, and respiratory depression. The presentations of specific depressant intoxication and withdrawal features are summarized in the table below.  



Option Analysis

❌ Miosis  :
Incorrect: Miosis (pinpoint pupils) is a typical feature of opioid intoxication. Additional findings include depressed respiratory rate, depressed consciousness, hypotension, and bradycardia. This patient’s history of chronic alcohol use and his current presentation with tremors, anxiety, and nausea instead suggest underlying alcohol withdrawal.
❌ Nasal septum perforation:
Incorrect: Cocaine intoxication manifests with agitation, diaphoresis, and mydriatic pupils. Nasal septum perforation may occur secondary to the caustic effects of the drug on the nasal mucosa. This patient’s history of chronic alcohol use and his current presentation with tremors, anxiety, and nausea instead suggest underlying alcohol withdrawal.
✅ Tongue fasciculations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Vertical nystagmus:
Incorrect: Vertical nystagmus can be seen with alcohol intoxication or in phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication.  PCP intoxication presents with agitation and aggression often requiring both chemical and physical restraints. This patient’s history of chronic alcohol use and his current presentation with tremors, anxiety, and nausea instead suggest underlying alcohol withdrawal.  
❌ Conjunctival injection  :
Incorrect: Marijuana intoxication can present with perception of slowed time, euphoria, anxiety, paranoid delusions, impaired judgment, social withdrawal, increased appetite, dry mouth, and conjunctival injection. This patient’s history of chronic alcohol use and his current presentation with tremors, anxiety, and nausea instead suggest underlying alcohol withdrawal.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits the office for follow-up after hospitalization for alcohol withdrawal and opiate dependence. Since discharge, the patient has mostly abstained from alcohol and opioid usage and is scared to use heavily again. The patient says, “I am trying to cut down on my alcohol intake, but my cravings are too strong.” Past medical history includes hypertension, chronic back pain, type 2 diabetes mellitus, alcohol use disorder, opioid use disorder, and recently diagnosed alcoholic cirrhosis. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. In addition to psychological interventions, the patient is provided with a medication that acts by increasing GABA-nergic pathways and diminishing the activity of glutamate in the central nervous system. Which of the following medications was most likely provided?
questions.solution:
This patient with concurrent alcohol use disorder and opioid use disorder desires to reduce his alcohol intake but struggles to control his cravings. Pharmacotherapy with acamprosate is the best treatment option for this patient. Acamprosate can be administered immediately following acute withdrawal. Its mechanism of action is not fully established, but it is structurally similar to gamma-amino-butyric acid (GABA). It is thought that this medication works to increase GABA-ergic pathways and diminish the activity of glutamate in the CNS.

Naltrexone is another highly effective medication used to treat alcohol dependence. It is a mu-opioid receptor antagonist that blocks the euphoric and some of the intoxicating effects of alcohol. This medication serves to help people with alcohol use disorder by reducing heavy drinking–enough so that patients remain motivated to continue treatment and avoid relapse. However, this medication cannot be utilized in patients with concurrent opioid use.

Finally, disulfiram is a second-line medication that is effective for highly motivated patients with alcohol use disorder. It works by inhibiting the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. In hepatocytes, alcohol is converted to acetaldehyde, which is further metabolized by aldehyde dehydrogenase. When this enzyme is inhibited, acetaldehyde levels accumulate–resulting in the immediate effects of a "hangover" following alcohol consumption (i.e. nausea/vomiting, tachycardia, flushing, and headache). This unpleasant physical reaction is the reason disulfiram is typically reserved for patients who have already stopped using alcohol – in these cases, disulfiram is helpful as a deterrent from future drinking.  

Option Analysis

❌ Disulfiram  :
Incorrect: Disulfiram is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor used effectively to treat alcohol dependence disorder when the patient is not actively drinking (unlike this patient, who reports “mostly” abstaining from alcohol). It is an aversive agent which causes a severe physical reaction (e.g., nausea/vomiting, tachycardia, flushing, and headache) whenever alcohol is consumed. It is the second-line agent for the treatment of alcohol dependence in highly motivated patients.  
❌ Chlordiazepoxide  :
Incorrect: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine that is effective in managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms, but it is not used for chronically managing alcohol use disorder.  
✅ Acamprosate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is an antidote for opioid overdose. It is not an effective treatment for alcohol use disorder.  
❌ Naltrexone  :
Incorrect: Naltrexone is the first-line pharmacotherapy for alcohol use disorder. It can be initiated while the patient is still drinking and is administered orally. However, concurrent opioid use (as in this patient) is a major contraindication to its use.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department to evaluate right arm swelling and pain. The patient also reports fever, chills, and rigors. The patient has a past medical history of depression, for which he takes escitalopram. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a right arm that is erythematous, swollen, and tender to touch. There is also mild bruising in the antecubital fossa of the same arm. The patient is admitted and started on intravenous antibiotics with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications prescribed for pain as needed. The following morning, the patient reports improved arm swelling and pain but endorses abdominal cramps, nausea, and myalgias. Physical examination demonstrates mydriasis, diaphoresis, and piloerection. This patient’s current presentation is consistent with withdrawal from the following substances?
questions.solution:
This patient with right upper extremity cellulitis has physical exam findings concerning for intravenous substance use (e.g. bruising in the antecubital fossa); after an overnight stay in the hospital, he subsequently experiences abdominal cramps, rhinorrhea, diaphoresis, nasal congestion, piloerection, myalgias, and mydriasis. This characteristic presentation suggests acute opioid withdrawal.

Opioid withdrawal occurs when a patient who is physiologically dependent upon opioids reduces or stops their use abruptly. Withdrawal symptoms typically develop within 6-12 hours of the last use and peak 24-48 hours after that. Common withdrawal symptoms include dysphoria, nausea or vomiting, muscle aches, lacrimation or rhinorrhea, piloerection or sweating, diarrhea, yawning, and insomnia.

It is critically important to non-judgmentally ask patients about their substance use, particularly in the setting of a hospital admission, so that pain can be managed appropriately and potential withdrawal symptoms can be managed proactively.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Alcohol  :
Incorrect: Alcohol withdrawal presents within 6-24 hours of the patient’s last drink with symptoms of diaphoresis, hypertension, tremor, and restlessness. This patient’s dilated pupils, piloerection, myalgias, and abdominal pain are more specific to opioid withdrawal.  
❌ Cocaine  :
Incorrect: Abrupt withdrawal from cocaine presents with increased appetite, hypersomnia, irritability, and fatigue. Depressive symptoms may also occur. This patient’s dilated pupils, piloerection, myalgias, and abdominal pain are more specific to opioid withdrawal.  
❌ Methamphetamine  :
Incorrect: Abrupt withdrawal from a stimulant like methamphetamine presents with increased appetite, hypersomnia, irritability, and fatigue. This patient’s dilated pupils, piloerection, myalgias, and abdominal pain are more specific to opioid withdrawal.  
✅ Heroin  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Escitalopram:
Incorrect: Abrupt discontinuation of SSRIs can present with a discontinuation syndrome characterized by dizziness, fatigue, headache, and myalgias. This patient’s dilated pupils, piloerection, myalgias, and abdominal pain are more specific to opioid withdrawal.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman with a history of alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department to evaluate worsening forgetfulness and frequent falls. The patient cannot recall the address of the house where she has been living for the past 30 years. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 103/61 mmHg. Physical examination shows an unkempt female with an ataxic gait. Ophthalmoplegia is noted on cranial nerve testing, and there is decreased vibration sensation in the bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory results are shown below. An MRI of the brain demonstrates atrophy of the anterior thalamus and mammillary bodies. Deficiency of which of the following nutrients is responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with encephalopathy, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia–consistent with the classic triad observed in patients with Wernicke encephalopathy (WE), a complication of thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.

Alcohol use disorder results in decreased intake, absorption, and hepatic storage of thiamine; it is the most important risk factor associated with the development of WE. Thiamine serves as a cofactor for multiple enzymes involved in cerebral glucose metabolism–particularly in the mammillary bodies. Korsakoff syndrome is a late neurologic complication of WE characterized by antegrade and retrograde amnesia, apathy, lack of insight, and confabulation.

Any patient suspected of having Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome should be promptly given high-dose IV thiamine. A note that administration of glucose/dextrose prior to thiamine can exacerbate symptoms, and it is generally preferred to administer thiamine first or concurrently with glucose/dextrose. Patients with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome should be thoroughly evaluated for associated nutritional and electrolyte deficiencies, which are common in this population.   

Option Analysis

❌ Ascorbic acid  :
Incorrect: Scurvy results from vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency and is characterized by bleeding gums, petechiae, and subperiosteal hemorrhages. This patient’s memory impairment, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Zinc:
Incorrect: Zinc deficiency is characterized by acrodermatitis enteropathica, growth retardation, and infertility. This patient’s memory impairment, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
✅ Thiamine  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Riboflavin  :
Incorrect: Riboflavin deficiency is characterized by oral manifestations including cheilosis, stomatitis, and glossitis. This patient’s memory impairment, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Cyanocobalamin  :
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (degeneration of both dorsal column and corticospinal tract pathways), and peripheral neuropathy. This patient’s memory impairment, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia suggest an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department to evaluate abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The patient describes pain that is localized to the right upper quadrant and is reproducible when she presses on the area. Past medical history includes alcohol use disorder, illicit drug use, and hepatitis C cirrhosis. The patient undergoes a transabdominal right upper quadrant ultrasound, and a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis is established. The patient is subsequently admitted and scheduled for an open cholecystectomy. The following day, the patient alerts the nurse of “insects crawling on my skin.” Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates an alert and oriented female with slight tremulousness and diaphoresis. In order to help manage her symptoms, the patient is provided with a medication that acts on the GABAA receptor. Which of the following medications was most likely provided?
questions.solution:
This hospitalized patient is experiencing an abrupt onset of tactile hallucinations, tremulousness, and diaphoresis; in combination with her history of alcohol use disorder, this presentation is typical of alcoholic hallucinosis. This condition manifests with hallucinations that develop within 12 to 24 hours of abstinence from alcohol.

Alcohol withdrawal is managed via a combination of electrolyte correction, vital sign monitoring, thiamine/folate supplementation (to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy), and sedative-hypnotic administration (benzodiazepines) to mitigate the effects of withdrawal. Lorazepam is the drug of choice in patients with a history of liver cirrhosis (as seen in this patient) due to its shorter half-life and inactive metabolites. Other medications used to treat the effects of withdrawal include chlordiazepoxide, diazepam, and phenobarbital.

The timing and characterization of the various manifestations of alcohol withdrawal are outlined in the chart and graph below.  



Option Analysis

❌ Haloperidol  :
Incorrect: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication that should be avoided in patients with alcohol withdrawal as it lowers the seizure threshold.  
✅ Lorazepam  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Methadone  :
Incorrect: Methadone is a long-acting opioid commonly used as maintenance therapy in patients with a history of opioid withdrawal and heroin addiction. Although this patient has a history of illicit drug use, her symptoms are more typical of alcohol withdrawal.
❌ Fomepizole  :
Incorrect: Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase and is the drug of choice in patients with ethylene glycol or methanol poisoning. There is insufficient evidence for its role in treating the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of altered mental status and slurred speech. Past medical history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder, major depressive disorder, and panic disorder. Current medications include amitriptyline and clonazepam. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 117/68 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a drowsy female who responds incoherently to questions. On neurological examination, pupils are 4 mm bilaterally and reactive to light. The abdomen is nontender, non-distended, and bowel sounds are normoactive. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no nystagmus or hand tremor appreciated. The patient tries to get up to use the restroom during the evaluation and nearly falls due to an ataxic gait. Laboratory results are shown below. Initial ECG is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  
Laboratory value
Result
Sodium  
140 mEq/L
Potassium  
4.1 mEq/L
Chloride  
102 mEq/L
HCO3-
24 mEq/L
Creatinine
0.6 g/dL  
BUN  
10 mg/dL
Glucose
120 mg/dL  
AST  
20 U/L  
ALT
25 U/L  
Total bilirubin  
0.3 mg/dL  
Alcohol  
negative
questions.solution:
This patient who is currently taking clonazepam presents with altered mental status, gait ataxia, and normal pupils and serum studies. Together, this presentation is consistent with benzodiazepine toxicity.

Benzodiazepine overdose typically results in CNS depression and lethargy without hemodynamic compromise. Benzodiazepine overdose can be life-threatening, especially when combined with alcohol, opioids, barbiturates, first-generation antihistamines (e.g. diphenhydramine), or other respiratory or CNS depressants. Patients with benzodiazepine intoxication should be carefully observed and conservatively managed, emphasizing airway and respiratory monitoring.

Flumazenil can precipitate withdrawal symptoms and seizures in patients with BZD dependence and is rarely recommended. The use of this medication should be reserved for critically ill patients with benzodiazepine overdose.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  


Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen overdose  :
Incorrect: Patients with acetaminophen overdose can present nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and malaise. Severe intoxication would cause liver damage and elevated liver enzymes (AST/ALT in the thousands).  
❌ Organophosphate poisoning  :
Incorrect: Organophosphate poisoning can present with symptoms of cholinergic hyperactivity such as bradycardia, miosis, bronchorrhea, salivation, and lacrimation. This patient’s symptoms are inconsistent with those of organophosphate poisoning.  
✅ Clonazepam overdose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amitriptyline overdose:
Incorrect: Patients with tricyclic antidepressant overdose typically present with cardiovascular, anticholinergic, and neurologic manifestations. This patient is without associated anticholinergic features.  
❌ Ethylene glycol poisoning  :
Incorrect: Patients with ethylene glycol poisoning can present with abdominal pain, vomiting, and altered mental status. In addition, patients typically present with an increased osmolar gap and anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient’s bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels are normal.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious in his car by a family member. The family member states that the patient has a history of polysubstance use. The patient is not taking any medications per a review of his medical records. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 5/min, and blood pressure is 120/87 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient is obtunded and minimally responsive to pain. Physical examination demonstrates 1 mm pupils bilaterally. Fingerstick blood glucose is 70 mg/dL. Supplemental oxygen, an ampule of dextrose, and intravenous fluids are administered. The patient is provided with a pure opiate antagonist for overdose reversal. Which of the following medications was provided?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, bradypnea (respiratory rate <12/min), and pinpoint pupils–characteristic findings of an acute opioid intoxication. Other clinical manifestations of this condition include orthostatic hypotension, nausea and vomiting (especially in opioid-naive patients), bronchospasm, ileus, urinary retention, hypoglycemia, and histamine release resulting in localized urticaria.

Opioid overdose is a medical emergency requiring close monitoring of vital signs and immediate pharmacological intervention. Management includes immediate assessment of the airway, providing ventilation if needed, administering intravenous fluids, and administering naloxone. This medication is a mu-opioid antagonist administered intranasally, intravenously, or subcutaneously and is the first-line treatment of acute overdose. Naloxone rapidly reverses the respiratory depression and sedation induced by opiates and is often a life-saving intervention.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Flumazenil  :
Incorrect: Flumazenil is used to treat benzodiazepine overdose, which is characterized by somnolence, diplopia, impaired balance, impaired motor function, anterograde amnesia, ataxia, and slurred speech.  
✅ Naloxone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fomepizole:
Incorrect: Fomepizole is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor and is the drug of choice for the treatment of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning. This patient’s decreased respirations and pinpoint pupils suggest acute opioid intoxication, which is treated with naloxone.  
❌ Buprenorphine  :
Incorrect: Buprenorphine (a partial opioid agonist) serves as an effective alternative to methadone in the management of opioid withdrawal and ongoing maintenance therapy for opioid use disorder. However, this patient’s decreased respirations and pinpoint pupils suggest acute opioid intoxication, which is treated with naloxone.
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat cardiotoxicity associated with tricyclic antidepressants overdose. It works by increasing serum pH and extracellular sodium–thus alleviating fast sodium channel blockade. This patient’s decreased respirations and pinpoint pupils suggest acute opioid intoxication, which is treated with naloxone.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department for restlessness and gastrointestinal symptoms for the past 24 hours. The patient reports 3-4 episodes of severe abdominal cramps followed by bouts of diarrhea. Since this morning, he has also had four episodes of vomiting following persistent nausea. Past medical history is significant for polysubstance use and alcohol use disorder. Family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 15/min and blood pressure is 157/92 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates mydriasis, rhinorrhea, yawning, and diaphoresis. Bowel sounds are increased on abdominal auscultation. Methadone is administered to the patient, which results in the resolution of his symptoms. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of polysubstance use presents with restlessness, abdominal cramps,  nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, rhinorrhea, diaphoresis, and mydriasis; this presentation is highly suggestive of acute opioid withdrawal.

Opioid withdrawal occurs when a patient who is physiologically dependent upon opioids reduces or stops their use abruptly. Withdrawal symptoms typically develop within 6-12 hours of the last use and peak 24-48 hours after that. Common withdrawal symptoms include dysphoria, nausea or vomiting, muscle aches, lacrimation or rhinorrhea, piloerection or sweating, diarrhea, yawning, and insomnia.

The symptoms of opiate withdrawal can be managed with either opioids or non-opioid adjuncts. Low-dose methadone, a long-acting opioid agonist, is usually sufficient to relieve acute withdrawal symptoms without producing severe intoxicating effects. It is often used in combination with adjunctive medications, including alpha-2 adrenergic agonists (e.g. clonidine), benzodiazepines (e.g. lorazepam), antiemetics (e.g. promethazine), and antidiarrheals (e.g. loperamide). Buprenorphine (a partial opioid agonist) is an effective alternative to methadone.

It is critically important to non-judgmentally ask patients about their substance use, particularly in the setting of a hospital admission, so that pain can be managed appropriately and potential withdrawal symptoms can be managed proactively.  


Option Analysis

✅ Long-acting opioid agonist  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor  :
Incorrect: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (e.g. escitalopram) are the agents of choice for treatment of major depressive disorder–not opioid withdrawal. This patient’s dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, and gastrointestinal symptoms are instead characteristic of opioid withdrawal, which can be managed with methadone, a long-acting opioid agonist.  
❌ Selective GABAA receptor antagonist  :
Incorrect: Flumazenil is a competitive inhibitor used in the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose, which is characterized by somnolence, diplopia, impaired balance, impaired motor function, anterograde amnesia, ataxia, and slurred speech. This patient’s presentation is more characteristic of opioid withdrawal, which can be managed with methadone, a long-acting opioid agonist.
❌ Opioid receptor antagonist  :
Incorrect: Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist; it is the drug of choice for treatment of acute opioid overdose. Opioid intoxication presents decreased mental status, depressed respiratory rate, and pinpoint pupils. This patient’s dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, and gastrointestinal symptoms are instead characteristic of opioid withdrawal, which can be managed with methadone, a long-acting opioid agonist.  
❌ Alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor  :
Incorrect: Fomepizole is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor and is the drug of choice for treating methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning. This patient’s dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, and gastrointestinal symptoms are instead characteristic of opioid withdrawal, which can be managed with methadone, a long-acting opioid agonist.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found sleeping on the sidewalk. The patient appears stuporous and is unable to provide a history. On chart review, past medical history includes hospitalization four weeks ago for epigastric abdominal pain and an inability to tolerate oral intake. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.86°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 100/65 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates moderate limb ataxia and slurred speech. The patient has evidence of nystagmus. The remainder of the physical exam is within normal limits. Laboratory evaluation is demonstrated below. Urine drug screen is negative. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with unexplained drowsiness, hypotension, gait ataxia, and slurred speech, consistent with acute alcohol intoxication. In addition, he has laboratory evidence of anemia, macrocytosis, and AST:ALT > 2. These findings, in combination with his recent hospitalization suspicious for pancreatitis, are concerning for a history of chronic alcohol use.

Acute alcohol intoxication is a common presentation to emergency departments. Clinically, alcohol intoxication is characterized by slurred speech, nystagmus, disinhibited behavior, incoordination, ataxia, memory impairment, stupor, or coma. Hypotension and tachycardia may occur as a result of ethanol-induced peripheral vasodilation or secondary to volume loss.

Laboratory evaluation in patients with chronic alcohol use may show evidence of anemia with macrocytosis and, in severe cases, pancytopenia. In addition, alcohol-related liver damage manifesting in the form of AST to ALT ratio of 2:1 or an elevated gamma-glutamyl transferase may be observed.

Blood alcohol content (BAC) is not a basis for the diagnosis of intoxication itself, but it can be a marker for the severity of the intoxication. However, it should be noted that the clinical manifestations of various BAC levels can vary significantly in patients with a history of chronic alcohol use who may have an increased tolerance. Other markers of alcohol intoxication that can be helpful include carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT) and phosphatidyl ethanol (PEth) levels.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated serum ethanol level  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intraparenchymal brain hemorrhage on CT  :
Incorrect: This patient is without evidence of head injury or concerning neurologic features (e.g., papilledema, pupillary abnormalities, loss of sensory/motor function, etc.), making an intracranial pathology less likely. In addition, the physical exam and laboratory features are more consistent with acute alcohol intoxication.  
❌ Dilated left atrium on echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Echocardiogram can be considered in patients with altered mental status in the context of stroke evaluation. While this patient does have slurred speech and an altered level of consciousness, he does not have localized symptoms concerning for a stroke (e.g. unilateral loss of sensory/motor function), and his physical exam and laboratory features are more consistent with acute alcohol intoxication.  
❌ Generalized spikes on electroencephalogram  :
Incorrect: An electroencephalogram (EEG) is utilized in the workup of patients with a first-time seizure. Though this patient’s slurred speech and ataxic gait could be secondary to postictal Todd paralysis, a generalized seizure would not explain this patient’s nystagmus or laboratory findings, which are more concerning for acute alcohol intoxication and chronic alcohol use, respectively.  
❌ Elevated serum acetaminophen level  :
Incorrect: Serum acetaminophen levels are ordered in patients with suspected poisoning or attempted suicided. Acetaminophen overdose presents with nausea, vomiting, right upper quadrant pain and laboratory evidence of acute hepatotoxicity (transaminitis in the thousands and hyperbilirubinemia). This patient’s physical exam and laboratory features are more consistent with acute alcohol intoxication.  

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate nausea, slurred speech, and altered level of consciousness. Past medical history includes alcohol use disorder, type 2 diabetes mellitus, benign essential tremor, intravenous drug use, chronic pain, and depression. Medications include metformin, primidone, methadone, and escitalopram. The patient’s spouse reports the patient has been particularly depressed after the recent death of his mother. While awaiting evaluation, the patient suddenly becomes unresponsive. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 89/58 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a lethargic patient who localizes to pain in response to sternal rub. The pupils are 3 mm bilaterally and reactive to light. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is subsequently intubated and admitted to the intensive care unit. Twenty-four hours later, the patient does not pass spontaneous breathing trials for extubation. Which of the following substances is the most likely etiology of this patient’s current condition?  
Laboratory value
Result  
Sodium
140 mEq/L  
Potassium  
4.1 mEq/L
Chloride
102 mEq/L
HCO3-  
24 mEq/L  
Serum  

Creatinine  
0.6 g/dL
BUN  
10 mg/dL  
Glucose  
120 mg/dL  
Alcohol  
300 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of benign essential tremor (commonly treated with primidone, which metabolizes to phenobarbital and phenylethylmalonic acid) presents with altered mental status, somnolence, bradypnea, and prolonged respiratory depression. Together, these findings are suspicious for barbiturate toxicity – which may have been precipitated by a primidone overdose.

Clinical features of mild-to-moderate barbiturate intoxication include lethargy, slurred speech, nystagmus, and ataxia. With higher doses, hypotension, coma, and respiratory arrest occur. In a deep barbiturate coma, the pupils appear small or mid-position, and the patient may lose all neurological reflexes. Pulmonary complications (e.g., atelectasis, edema, and bronchopneumonia) and renal failure are the potentially fatal complications of severe barbiturate overdose. Patients should be managed with general supportive measures, including mechanical ventilation as needed. Forced diuresis and alkalinization of the urine (sodium bicarbonate) will hasten the excretion of phenobarbital.

Withdrawal symptoms include anxiety, nausea and vomiting, hypotension, seizures, and psychosis. Rarely, cardiovascular collapse may occur in patients undergoing acute withdrawal from barbiturates, so patients recovering from an overdose should be monitored closely for severe withdrawal symptoms.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Cocaine  :
Incorrect: Cocaine intoxication presents with euphoria, agitation, psychosis, and elevated pulse and blood pressure. Intoxication with cocaine would not cause the slurred speech, decreased level of consciousness, and depressed respiratory drive observed in this patient.  
❌ Ecstasy  :
Incorrect: Ecstasy is a synthetic amphetamine that presents with euphoria, hypertension, tachycardia hyperthermia, and in rare cases, serotonin syndrome. Intoxication with ecstasy would not cause the slurred speech, decreased level of consciousness, and depressed respiratory drive observed in this patient.  
✅ Barbiturates  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mephedrone  :
Incorrect: Mephedrone is the most commonly encountered agent in bath salts, and intoxication manifests with agitation, combative behavior, and psychosis. It is unlikely to cause the decreased level of consciousness and depressed respiratory drive observed in this patient.  
❌ Alcohol  :
Incorrect: Ethanol intoxication presents with slurred speech, emotional lability, an ataxic gait, and obtundation in high doses. While this patient had a high blood alcohol level on initial presentation, ethanol intoxication alone would not explain his continued obtundation and inability to pass spontaneous breathing trials. Alcohol is cleared at a rate of about 20-30 mg/dL/hour. Thus, his approximate level after 24 hours in the hospital would be 300 mg/dL - (20 mg/dL/hour * 24) = 0 mg/dL.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a head-on motor vehicle collision. Trauma workup demonstrates a fracture of the right femur and tibia for which the patient is admitted and scheduled for surgical repair the next day. Twelve hours after admission, the patient becomes agitated, hypervigilant, and paranoid. He repeatedly tells the nurse that he hears voices calling out his name and someone is planning to kill him. He frequently attempts to remove his morphine PCA pump. Past medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder, opioid use disorder, and moderate marijuana use. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), a pulse is 88/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 135/87 mmHg. Physical examination shows an alert and oriented male with tremulousness and diaphoresis. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with auditory hallucinations, stable vital signs, and a past history of alcohol use disorder; his current presentation is therefore suggestive of alcoholic hallucinosis.

The symptoms of alcohol withdrawal generally begin within 12-24 hours of the last intake and comprise a range of symptoms of varying clinical severity. In general, withdrawal features include autonomic hyperactivity, tremors, insomnia, nausea and vomiting, transient hallucinations (usually visual but can also be auditory and tactile), psychomotor agitation, anxiety, and tonic-clonic seizures. Symptoms may be mild for many patients, but if left untreated, alcohol withdrawal can lead to delirium tremens (within 48-96 hours). This uncommon but severe and life-threatening manifestation of withdrawal is marked by severe hallucinations, disorientation, and autonomic overactivity. The timing and characterization of the various manifestations of alcohol withdrawal are outlined in the chart and graph below.
 



Option Analysis

❌ Heroin withdrawal  :
Incorrect: Heroin withdrawal typically presents with dysphoria, restlessness, rhinorrhea, myalgias, and arthralgias. This patient is receiving a continuous infusion of morphine, making opiate withdrawal unlikely.  
✅ Alcohol hallucinosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Phencyclidine intoxication  :
Incorrect: Phencyclidine intoxication presents with psychomotor symptoms (e.g., agitation, aggression), delirium, ataxia, and dissociative symptoms. Persistent PCP intoxication this far into this patient’s clinical course is unlikely given the drug's fast metabolism.  
❌ Fat embolism  :
Incorrect: Fat embolism is a life-threatening complication of long bone fractures and manifests within 24 to 72 hours following the initial insult. Features include hypoxemia, dyspnea, tachypnea, anxiety, altered level of consciousness, and a petechial rash. This patient’s hallucinations and stable vital signs are instead suggestive of alcoholic hallucinosis.  
❌ Delirium tremens  :
Incorrect: Delirium tremens (DT) is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal and presents with confusion, tachycardia, hypertension, and agitation 48-96 hours after the last intake. This patient has stable vitals and has been in the hospital for 12 hours, making DT less likely.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the effects of alcohol on sleep. Alcohol is administered prior to nocturnal sleep to assess its physiological impact on sleep variables in healthy volunteers and control samples. Which of the following is most likely to be true in the patients given alcohol?
questions.solution:
Alcohol is widely used as a sleep-inducing agent in the population, particularly in individuals with insomnia. However, the quality of sleep changes since alcohol has a significant impact on sleep architecture.

Alcohol is able to decrease sleep latency, which is defined as the amount of time from full wakefulness to sleep onset. Likewise, alcohol increases total night sleep time, which is defined as the amount of time a person actually spends asleep during a planned sleep episode. These are two reasons why alcohol is utilized as a sleep-inducing agent. However, the ability to fall asleep faster is often negated by the adverse effects alcohol has on the remainder of the sleep cycle. For instance, alcohol reduces the amount of slow-wave sleep (stage N3). During this stage, delta waves can be seen on the EEG waveform; these waves are characterized by the lowest frequency and highest amplitude. Alcohol also decreases the total amount of REM sleep. These two phases of sleep are important for memory consolidation, learning, and brain development.

Depression is a medical condition that also significantly impacts sleep architecture. Patients with depression characteristically have increased total REM sleep but decreased REM latency, which is defined as the amount of time from the onset of sleep to the onset of REM sleep.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased total night REM sleep   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Increased sleep latency   :
Incorrect: Sleep latency is defined as the amount of time from full wakefulness to sleep onset. Alcohol is known to decrease, as opposed to increase, sleep latency.   
❌ REM sleep without atonia   :
Incorrect: Loss of normal REM sleep atonia is a feature of REM sleep behavior disorder, which is a parasomnia wherein patients act out their dreams. The condition can occur independently or be a hallmark of various neurodegenerative disorders (e.g., Parkinson disease, Lewy body dementia, multiple system atrophy). Alcohol is not known to cause REM sleep without atonia.   
❌ Decreased total sleep time   :
Incorrect: Total sleep time is the amount of time a person actually spends asleep during a planned sleep episode. It is usually increased in patients who consume alcohol.   
❌ Increased slow-wave sleep   :
Incorrect: Slow-wave sleep (SWS), also known as stage N3 sleep, is characterized by low frequency and high amplitude waves. SWS is typically decreased in patients who consume alcohol prior to sleeping.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is found unresponsive in the bathroom of a rest stop off the interstate highway. Upon the arrival of emergency services, the patient’s temperature is 35°C (95°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 5/min, and blood pressure is 88/60 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 89%. The patient is obtunded and minimally responsive to pain. Physical examination in the field reveals multiple track marks on the arms bilaterally. The pupils are 1 mm bilaterally. During the paramedic evaluation, the patient suffers a cardiac arrest, and despite aggressive resuscitation measures, the patient dies en route to the hospital. Post mortem toxicology is most likely to reveal which of the following agents as the cause of death?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple characteristic features of the opiate toxidrome–miosis, respiratory depression, and decreased level of consciousness. Overdose with opioid analgesics is the most common cause of drug overdose death in adults.

Clinically, opioid overdose presents with a spectrum of characteristic clinical features, including depressed respiratory rate and level of consciousness, miosis, hypoactive bowel sounds, hypotension, and bradycardia. An additional physical exam finding in patients who use heroin intravenously is evidence of track marks. The treatment for opioid overdose is naloxone, an inexpensive and effective antidote. All patients presenting with characteristic features of an opioid overdose, such as the patient described here, should promptly receive naloxone – an intervention which is often life-saving.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Ethanol  :
Incorrect: Alcohol withdrawal generally begins within 12-24 hours and is characterized by insomnia, tremor, anxiety, auditory hallucinations, and, in severe cases, a progression to delirium and life-threatening seizures (delirium tremens). This patient’s death more likely resulted from an opioid overdose.  
✅ Opiates  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Benzodiazepine:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepine overdose can present slurred speech, unsteady gait, and drowsiness. However, normal vital signs and pupillary size will distinguish it from opioid overdose.  
❌ Cannabinoids  :
Incorrect: Cannabis intoxication usually manifests with conjunctival injection, dry mouth, tachycardia, and increased appetite. Respiratory and central nervous system depression is not observed; severe physiologic effects are rare after cannabis use, and their presence should prompt the clinician to consider co-ingestion of other recreational drugs (including cocaine, amphetamines, and phencyclidine). This patient’s death more likely resulted from an opioid overdose.  
❌ Cocaine:
Incorrect: Cocaine is a stimulant and typically presents with dilated pupils, tachycardia, tachypnea, and increased sympathetic activity. This patient presented with miotic pupils and respiratory depression; therefore, this patient’s death more likely resulted from an opioid overdose.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic for follow-up after initiating a new medication for heroin relapse prevention. The patient states, “I feel a lot better, doctor. I think the medication you gave me is working. I have been using heroin less. I don’t get the same high anymore.” The patient experienced mild withdrawal symptoms after the initial sublingual administration of this medication several weeks ago. Which of the following best describes the medication's mechanism of action for this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor partial agonist.
κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor antagonist or partial agonist

questions.solution:
This patient was provided with a sublingual medication to prevent heroin relapse. He was most likely prescribed buprenorphine, a μ-opioid receptor partial agonist.    

The withdrawal symptoms this patient experienced were secondary to consuming this medication concurrently with a full opiate agonist. The pharmacodynamics of these medications can explain this phenomenon. Recall that partial agonists alone act as agonists at their target receptor. However, in the presence of a full agonist, molecules of the partial agonist can displace drug molecules of the full agonist and result in a net decrease in receptor activation. As a result, symptoms of opiate withdrawal can develop. Additional medications that can cause a similar phenomenon include those with mixed agonist/antagonist effects at opiate receptors (e.g., nalbuphine, pentazocine, butorphanol).    

As a result, withdrawal symptoms may arise when medications like buprenorphine are administered to patients taking full opiate agonists (e.g., heroin, morphine, fentanyl). However, when administered alone, buprenorphine produces an analgesic effect. Moreover, buprenorphine has a ceiling effect on respiratory depression ceiling, which helps prevent dangerous overdose.   

Option Analysis

✅ μ-opioid receptor partial agonism:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ μ-opioid receptor agonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of medications such as morphine, hydromorphone, or fentanyl. These medications are not typically used in the prevention of heroin relapse. In contrast, this patient was most likely prescribed buprenorphine, a μ-opioid receptor partial agonist.  
❌ μ-opioid receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of naloxone. This medication is used to reverse acute opioid intoxication, but not in long-term prevention of relapse.  
❌ κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor partial agonist.:
Incorrect: Butorphanol is used to treat severe pain. Administration of this medication may precipitate severe, acute withdrawal symptoms due to its partial agonist effects. It is not used in the management of opiate dependence relapse prevention.    
❌ κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor antagonist or partial agonist  :
Incorrect: Like butorphanol, pentazocine is used to treat severe acute pain. This injectable medication has strong effects on κ-opioid receptors, which may result in dysphoria. It is not used in the management of opiate dependence relapse prevention.
